thread.title: Toshiba won't cancel $18 billion chip deal unless any major material change - CEO

title: Toshiba won't cancel $18 billion chip deal unless any major material change - CEO
text:
April 3, 2018 / 9:34 AM / Updated 3 minutes ago Toshiba won't cancel $18 billion chip deal unless any major material change - CEO Reuters Staff 2 Min Read 
TOKYO (Reuters) - Toshiba Corp ( 6502.T ) will not use the option of cancelling the $18 billion (£12.7 billion) sale of its memory chip unit unless there is any “major material change” in circumstances, the Japanese conglomerate’s new chief executive said on Tuesday. FILE PHOTO - The logo of Toshiba Corp. is seen at the company's facility in Kawasaki, Japan February 13, 2017. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo 
Toshiba was unable to complete the sale to a consortium led by U.S. private equity firm Bain Capital LP by the agreed deadline of March 31 as it was still waiting for approval from China’s anti-monopoly regulator. 
Under the agreement, Toshiba now has the option to cancel the sale without forfeit. Cancelling would give Toshiba the freedom to pursue alternative courses of action, such as renegotiating the sale or conducting an initial public offering - a move activist shareholders have urged Toshiba to consider. 
“We will maintain our stance and wait (for Chinese regulatory approval) unless drastic changes occur,” Nobuaki Kurumatani told reporters. Toshiba aims to complete the sale as soon as possible, he said. 
Asked what was meant by drastic change, he cited the failure to receive Chinese regulatory approval or some unforeseen situation involving the consortium. 
He declined to comment on any plans should the deal fail to receive approval by the annual shareholders’ meeting in June. 
Kurumatani this month became the first outsider to lead Toshiba in half a century as the conglomerate works to recover from the worst years in its 142-year history after a $1.3 billion accounting scandal and the bankruptcy of its U.S. nuclear power subsidiary. Reporting by Makiko YamazakiEditing by Christopher Cushing
